programs.description: This program represents a large cluster of genes encoding structural and regulatory components of motile cilia axonemes. The genes include multiple CFAP (cilia and flagella associated protein) family members (CFAP43, CFAP52, CFAP61, CFAP73, CFAP206, CFAP47, CFAP221, CFAP157, CFAP100), dynein arm proteins (DNAH12, DNAH5, DRC1, DNAAF1), radial spoke components (RSPH1), and axonemal assembly regulators (TTC29, TOGARAM2, LRRIQ1). These proteins collectively assemble and regulate the 9+2 microtubule structure characteristic of motile cilia. While motile cilia are not typically associated with differentiated glioblastoma cells, primary cilia play critical roles in glioma biology through Hedgehog signaling and other pathways. The aberrant expression of motile ciliary genes may reflect dedifferentiation, stem-like features, or ectopic developmental program activation in malignant glioblastoma.

programs.evidence_summary: The co-expression of numerous ciliary axoneme components is highly unusual in differentiated brain cells but reflects a coordinated developmental program. In glioblastoma, primary cilia regulate Hedgehog signaling and tumor growth. While these specific motile ciliary genes are not typically expressed in adult brain, their presence may indicate ectopic developmental program activation, dedifferentiation toward ciliated progenitor states, or co-option of ciliary machinery for alternative cellular functions.

programs.description: This program encompasses genes encoding structural collagens (COL21A1, COL13A1, COL23A1, COL26A1), matricellular proteins (THBS1, POSTN), and basement membrane components (HMCN1). Thrombospondin-1 (THBS1) is particularly significant in glioblastoma, where it is upregulated at invasive tumor borders, promotes cell migration and invasion through CD47 interaction, and contributes to resistance to anti-angiogenic therapy. Periostin (POSTN) and collagen genes regulate the immunosuppressive tumor microenvironment and epithelial-mesenchymal transition. HMCN1, a fibulin family member and basement membrane component, is frequently mutated across cancers and may regulate tissue adhesion and invasion.

programs.evidence_summary: Extensive literature documents THBS1 as a key driver of glioblastoma invasion, particularly at tumor borders, where it shows highest connectivity in gene networks. THBS1 interacts with CD47 to promote invasion and is induced by TGF-beta signaling. Collagen genes including COL1A1, COL3A1, COL4A1, and related family members form an immunosuppressive signature in glioma associated with poor survival. HMCN1 is among the most frequently mutated ECM genes across cancers and may promote metastasis.

programs.description: This program includes GABA receptor subunits (GABRA5, GABRG3) and metabotropic glutamate receptors (GRM1, GRM4) that mediate inhibitory and excitatory neurotransmitter signaling. In glioblastoma, GABAergic signaling through GABA-A receptors can promote tumor growth through neuronal activity-dependent mechanisms. Glioma cells form functional neuron-glioma synapses and respond to GABAergic input, which can drive proliferation particularly in pediatric diffuse midline gliomas. GRM1 and GRM4 are part of neuroligin-3 and glutamate-mediated signaling that promotes glioma growth through neuronal activity.

GABA-A receptor activation drives proliferation through chloride transporter-mediated depolarization rather than hyperpolarization. Multiple studies show GABA receptors are aberrantly expressed in gliomas and that blocking GABAergic signaling can inhibit tumor growth.

programs.description: This program includes zinc finger transcription factors (ZNF521, ZNF804B, PLAGL1), chromatin remodeling factors (CHD5, SATB1-AS1), and epigenetic regulators (PRMT8, AFF2). ZNF521 synergizes with GLI transcription factors to enhance Hedgehog signaling, which is critical in glioma stem cells. PLAGL1 is a core marker of glioblastoma that drives edge-to-core transition and directly regulates CD109 expression. CHD5 functions as a tumor suppressor in multiple cancers including gliomas. PRMT8 regulates neuronal differentiation and is depleted in glioblastoma. These genes collectively regulate stem cell programs, differentiation, and oncogenic transcription.

programs.description: This program includes adenylate cyclase (ADCY8), kinase suppressor of RAS (KSR2), and MAP kinases (MAP3K19, MAP7) that regulate cAMP production and MAPK signaling. ADCY8 polymorphisms are sex-specific modifiers of glioma risk in neurofibromatosis type 1 patients. KSR2 regulates both ERK signaling and AMPK-dependent metabolism, and is essential for tumor cell energy homeostasis and anchorage-independent growth. The cAMP pathway regulates glioma proliferation, and its dysregulation contributes to tumorigenesis in a sexually dimorphic manner.

programs.description: This program includes neuregulin-3 (NRG3) and bone morphogenetic protein 6 (BMP6), which regulate neural development, stem cell differentiation, and tumor cell fate. NRG3 promotes glioma cell migration and invasion through enhanced L1CAM expression and is associated with immune cell infiltration. BMP signaling induces glioma stem cell quiescence and confers resistance to radiation and temozolomide by activating DNA repair machinery. The balance between TGF-beta and BMP signaling defines proliferative versus quiescent glioma stem cell states.

BMP-positive cells accumulate after chemoradiation and repopulate tumors at recurrence.

programs.description: This program includes multiple solute carrier family members (SLC14A1, SLC47A2, SLC22A3) that transport urea, organic cations, and drugs across cell membranes. SLC47A1 (homolog of SLC47A2) is highly expressed in glioma stem cells and correlates with malignancy and poor prognosis. SLC22A3 expression is a favorable prognostic biomarker in glioblastoma. These transporters regulate drug uptake, metabolite transport, and may influence chemotherapy sensitivity and tumor metabolism.

programs.description: This program includes B-cell marker BANK1, immune adaptor FYB2, and interleukin-6 receptor (IL6R) that reflect immune cell infiltration in the glioblastoma microenvironment. B-cells in glioblastoma can drive response to immune checkpoint blockade, and their infiltration correlates with therapeutic efficacy. IL6R signaling is implicated in glioma progression and immune modulation. The presence of these immune markers may reflect lymphocyte infiltration or expression by tumor cells themselves.

method.notes: Programs were identified through comprehensive literature analysis of gene functions in glioblastoma context. Genes were clustered based on shared biological processes (ciliary assembly, ECM remodeling, neurotransmission, transcriptional regulation, signaling pathways, transport, immune function). Each program was evaluated for evidence strength, relevance to glioblastoma, and number of supporting genes. Significance scores reflect literature support, number of genes, pathway completeness, and disease relevance.
